{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3564874,"name":"Micah","username":"Hyperspace1710","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hyperspace1710/{size}/194547_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T19:52:45.009Z","cooked":"

We’re looking around for different elevator height sensors at the moment and CANranges seem like they could be a solution. We used LaserCANs last year and experienced latency issues when reading data — has anyone experienced similar problems with CANranges?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T19:52:45.009Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":130.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496485,"topic_slug":"do-canranges-have-similar-amounts-of-output-latency-as-lasercans","display_username":"Micah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59402,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1710 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/do-canranges-have-similar-amounts-of-output-latency-as-lasercans/496485/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3565058,"name":"Jason Evans","username":"j.e","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/j.e/{size}/175324_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T00:51:22.447Z","cooked":"

I’m a bit perplexed by people claiming on ChiefDelphi that time of flight sensors are a good (presumably accurate and low-latency) way to measure elevator height. We started using time of flight sensors this season, including as a way to estimate elevator height during homing, and they’re also working well as proximity sensors on our effector.

We tested LaserCANs, the equivalent Playing With Fusion offering, and the Pololu distance sensor. They all behaved pretty similarly in our tests (mean error less than 10mm for all of them), so we chose the simplest and wrote a basic Pololu4079 subsystem around it. The only other challenge was designing a 3D-printed mount (actually 3 for our specific use cases).

As with most mechanisms, you’re better off using the motor’s built-in relative encoder to enable use of the motor controller’s PID control than you are using an external PID controller. You shouldn’t need to worry much about latency if you’re measuring elevator height only once while the mechanism is motionless, then using that measurement to initialize the motor’s relative encoder position. If you insist on using a time of flight sensor for continuous elevator height measurement, you’re going to fight latency and accuracy. If we tried this, I’d expect our elevator to continuously creep up and down as the sensor readings fluctuated. And that’s the happy case (no grossly invalid readings).

We started using custom string potentiometers this season in an attempt to avoid using continuous time-of-flight sensor readings.

j.e:

As with most mechanisms, you’re better off using the motor’s built-in relative encoder to enable use of the motor controller’s PID control than you are using an external PID controller. You shouldn’t need to worry much about latency if you’re measuring elevator height only once while the mechanism is motionless, then using that measurement to initialize the motor’s relative encoder position.

We’ll probably try this and see how it works. Thanks!
